column23:
In our case, the Github bugtracker is probably much too simple and would make our thousands of open bugs unmanageable. We also use a different git flow (Gerrit based) which suits us better.

As a compromise, our Gerrit instance allow people to log in with their Github account, as some devs says that having to create a dedicated account for us would stop people from contributing (I'm not sure I agree, if someone is not motivated enough to create an account, why would I think they could become contributors sending many patches?).

In the past we were hosted on 3rd party websites (sourceforge and berlios) and have learnt that nothing lasts forever and it is not wise to put our codebase and workflow in the hands of a 3rd party. As a result, wether it is an independant or Microsoft owned Github does not change anything: it still is a bad idea to rely on it for a large project.

column14: The problem is, if too much devs move to other platforms, then the greatest benefit of GitHib (easy cross-contribution and linking between different projects) will be lost. Thus follow the herd ;).
column24: For now, unless many other projects move fast (see last comment), I would stay with GitHub, but I am afraid of slowly typical Microsoft integrations, OneDrive, Skype, merge of GitHub and Microsoft account and such things. Would not surprise me but kills the whole idea of FOSS. I think the main reason why great open source related project fail, after big companies buy then, is that a large commercial company, which earn money the opposite way than FOSS related projects try, lack the needed feeling and motivation and relationship to/with the community to be able to bring it forward the right way. FOSS <> proprietary for me is simply an opposite approach. This of course cannot be tied to single people within e.g. Microsoft, but I think the company as a whole will slowly change GitHub in a way, that drives FOSS developers away, just because the idea of what is good and beneficial is simply a different one.

column19:
The problem is NOT GitHUB-Microsoft deal but more general, a small example: in the past we (nearly) all use usenet. There are TONS of newserver around the world, anyone can host another if he or she want. There are plenty of groups some fun, some about sport, some about work, some to help others, some to discuss new ideas, ... today we have FEW non-integrated proprietary platforms (from Fb to StackExchange to Reddit to 4Chan, YC, ... all of them are POOR replacements of ancient ng. All of them are proprietary and depend on a single company.

For GitHub (&co) the situation is the same: in the past (an few project keep this paradigma) we work on ml, we host projects on a variety of hosts, many are from project members itself (think at Debian's mirros by ISPs that use Debian). Now people tend to concentrate on single proprietary platform like GitHub, GitLab etc. It doesn't matter if the holder is Microsoft or Dr. Foo Bar: they are company, their goal is making money. We can have a common interest but it can't least forever. On open platforms when the interest diverge the switch is easy, for instance if you change your mail service it's a matter of IMAP transfert. If you switch from a proprietary platform to another MANY thing may change. It may be hard.

If the use of GitHub is limited as a repository mirror there are little issue, they are substantial "open hosters", but if you use PR&other GitHub features you are locked-in.
column24:
Today we need more than ever FREEDOM. We can have in a commercial world, we have had in the past in the USA, not in the URSS! But we need to know and understand and defend freedom.

Today and not since today our freedom is getting smaller and smaller from the hardware (UEFI (in)secure-boot etc) to services (how many people instead of have a local maildir sync-ed, for instance, only live on webmails?) to the society in general.

column14: The Debian project had always been in favour of not using services running on infrastructure that is not managed by Debian. Impact to the project has been minimal as we had already our own infrastructure (Alioth recently migrated to salsa.debian.org, our own gitlab infrastructure). Debian is used to handling upstream developers using many different forges (Sourceforge, Savannah, GitHub, Gitlab) and the impact of upstream moving from GitHub to GitSalsa has not been significant.

Your final question on page 2 needs to be completely redesigned. It is a mandatory question but there are other answers besides "everything uses Github", "nothing has ever used Github", and "one project I contribute to has left Github".

You never define what you mean by "Linux distributions". None of the major Linux distributions use Github directly for everything, but there are many projects packaged by Linux distributions that do use Github.

It feels like you haven't given enough thought about why people have their opinion of the Microsoft acquisition. Some people think Microsoft is the Evil Empire, others think that Microsoft is just another tech company and generally isn't evil these days. That is a big split in the open source community.

There is a huge irony with some open source people being upset at the Github thing when Github isn't even open source at all.

column24: GitHub is not the "silver bullet": some of the most successful projects in the world don't even use GitHub - or never used. That said, it's very sad for the OSS community that a company like Microsoft, that since its inception was an enemy of Open Source, acquired GitHub - they don't sell (to me) the idea that they are now a different company. They will have to do more to show so. So far they have done nothing compared to what they have arguably taken.

column14: Github has been core to projects I work on, including Chef and Samba. Moving would be awkward: but Microsoft could very easily destroy the trust critical to these projects, much as Sourceforge ruined trust in their repositories by poisoning the idle Windows GIMP project with adware. Trust in Microsoft's business practices is low, for strong historical reason, and it will take a long time to earn that trust.
